word_breakdown: Helô = hello
usage_note: Standard informal or friendly greeting in Welsh.
pattern_examples: Helô / Helo / Hylô
pattern_examples_en: Hello / Hi / Hey

word_breakdown: Hwyl = goodbye / fun
usage_note: Common informal way to say goodbye; also means 'fun'. Context decides meaning.
pattern_examples: Hwyl / Hwyl fawr
pattern_examples_en: Goodbye / Bye for now

word_breakdown: Bore = morning, da = good
usage_note: Used as a greeting in the morning; works in both formal and informal situations.
pattern_examples: Bore da / Prynhawn da / Noswaith dda
pattern_examples_en: Good morning / Good afternoon / Good evening

word_breakdown: Prynhawn = afternoon, da = good
usage_note: Used in the afternoon as a greeting; formal and informal.
pattern_examples: Prynhawn da / Bore da / Noswaith dda
pattern_examples_en: Good afternoon / Good morning / Good evening

word_breakdown: Noswaith = evening, dda = good (soft mutation of 'da')
usage_note: Used in the evening as a greeting; note the mutation from 'da' to 'dda'.
pattern_examples: Noswaith dda / Bore da / Nos da
pattern_examples_en: Good evening / Good morning / Good night

word_breakdown: Nos = night, da = good
usage_note: Used when saying good night or before going to sleep.
pattern_examples: Nos da / Noswaith dda / Bore da
pattern_examples_en: Good night / Good evening / Good morning

word_breakdown: Siôn = Siôn (name), dw i = I am
usage_note: Used to introduce yourself; replace 'Siôn' with your own name.
pattern_examples: Siôn dw i. / Mari dw i.
pattern_examples_en: I am Siôn / I am Mari

word_breakdown: Pwy = who, dych = are, chi = you (formal/plural)
usage_note: Formal or polite way to ask someone's identity.
pattern_examples: Pwy dych chi? / Pwy wyt ti?
pattern_examples_en: Who are you? (formal) / Who are you? (informal)

word_breakdown: Pwy = who, wyt = are, ti = you (informal)
usage_note: Informal way to ask someone's identity.
pattern_examples: Pwy wyt ti? / Pwy dych chi?
pattern_examples_en: Who are you? (informal) / Who are you? (formal)

word_breakdown: Sut = how, dych = are, chi = you (formal/plural)
usage_note: Formal or polite way to ask how someone is.
pattern_examples: Sut dych chi? / Sut wyt ti?
pattern_examples_en: How are you? (formal) / How are you? (informal)

word_breakdown: Sut = how, wyt = are, ti = you (informal)
usage_note: Informal way to ask how someone is.
pattern_examples: Sut wyt ti? / Sut dych chi?
pattern_examples_en: How are you? (informal) / How are you? (formal)

word_breakdown: Ble = where, dych = are, chi’n = you (are), byw = live
usage_note: Formal or polite way to ask where someone lives.
pattern_examples: Ble dych chi’n byw? / Ble rwyt ti’n byw?
pattern_examples_en: Where do you live? (formal) / Where do you live? (informal)

word_breakdown: Ble = where, rwyt = are, ti’n = you (are), byw = live
usage_note: Informal way to ask where someone lives.
pattern_examples: Ble rwyt ti’n byw? / Ble dych chi’n byw?
pattern_examples_en: Where do you live? (informal) / Where do you live? (formal)

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, byw = live, yn = in, Abertawe = Swansea
usage_note: Used to state where you live; Abertawe is the Welsh name for Swansea.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n byw yn Abertawe. / Dw i’n byw yn Llanelli.
pattern_examples_en: I live in Swansea / I live in Llanelli

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, byw = live, yn = in, Llanelli = Llanelli
usage_note: Used to state where you live; Llanelli is a town in South Wales.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n byw yn Llanelli. / Dw i’n byw yn Abertawe.
pattern_examples_en: I live in Llanelli / I live in Swansea

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, gyrru = driving, Hyundai = Hyundai (car brand)
usage_note: Used to say what car you drive.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n gyrru Hyundai. / Dw i’n gyrru Fiesta.
pattern_examples_en: I drive a Hyundai / I drive a Fiesta

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, gwylio = watching, Netflix = Netflix
usage_note: Used to say what you are watching.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n gwylio Netflix. / Dw i’n gwylio Strictly.
pattern_examples_en: I am watching Netflix / I am watching Strictly

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, darllen = reading, y = the, Telegraph = Telegraph
usage_note: Used to say what you are reading.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n darllen y Telegraph. / Dw i’n darllen y Western Mail.
pattern_examples_en: I am reading the Telegraph / I am reading the Western Mail

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, dysgu = learning, Cymraeg = Welsh
usage_note: Used to say you are learning the Welsh language.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n dysgu Cymraeg. / Dw i’n dysgu ychydig.
pattern_examples_en: I am learning Welsh / I am learning a little

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, hoffi = like, coffi = coffee
usage_note: Used to say you like coffee.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n hoffi coffi. / Dw i’n hoffi te.
pattern_examples_en: I like coffee / I like tea

welsh: Dw i ddim yn hoffi te.
image: media/image/Dw i ddim yn hoffi te..png
audio: media/audio/Dw i ddim yn hoffi te..m4a
example: Dw i ddim yn hoffi te.
phonetic: DOO ee thim un HOFF-ee teh
word_breakdown: Dw i ddim = I am not, yn = (linking particle), hoffi = like, te = tea
usage_note: Used to say you do not like tea.
pattern_examples: Dw i ddim yn hoffi te. / Dw i ddim yn hoffi coffi.
pattern_examples_en: I do not like tea / I do not like coffee

word_breakdown: Wyt = are (you), ti’n = you (are), hoffi = like, coffi = coffee
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone likes coffee.
pattern_examples: Wyt ti’n hoffi coffi? / Wyt ti’n hoffi te?
pattern_examples_en: Do you like coffee? / Do you like tea?

word_breakdown: Ydw = yes (I do), dw i’n = I am, hoffi = like, coffi = coffee
usage_note: Affirmative answer to a question about liking coffee.
pattern_examples: Ydw, dw i’n hoffi coffi. / Ydw, dw i’n hoffi te.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, I like coffee / Yes, I like tea

welsh: Nac ydw, dw i ddim yn hoffi coffi.
english: No, I do not like coffee.
image: media/image/Nac ydw, dw i ddim yn hoffi coffi..png
audio: media/audio/Nac ydw, dw i ddim yn hoffi coffi..m4a
example: Nac ydw, dw i ddim yn hoffi coffi.
phonetic: NAHK UHD-oo, DOO ee thim un HOFF-ee KOFF-ee
word_breakdown: Nac ydw = no (I do not), dw i ddim = I am not, yn = (linking particle), hoffi = like, coffi = coffee
usage_note: Negative answer to a question about liking coffee.
pattern_examples: Nac ydw, dw i ddim yn hoffi coffi. / Nac ydw, dw i ddim yn hoffi te.
pattern_examples_en: No, I do not like coffee / No, I do not like tea

word_breakdown: ’Dyn ni’n = we are, hoffi’r = like the, rhaglen = programme
usage_note: Used to say you like a particular programme.
pattern_examples: ’Dyn ni’n hoffi’r rhaglen. / ’Dyn ni’n hoffi’r dosbarth.
pattern_examples_en: We like the programme / We like the class

word_breakdown: Dych chi’n = you are (formal/plural), hoffi’r = like the, dosbarth = class
usage_note: Formal or polite way to ask if someone likes the class.
pattern_examples: Dych chi’n hoffi’r dosbarth? / Wyt ti’n hoffi’r dosbarth?
pattern_examples_en: Do you like the class? (formal) / Do you like the class? (informal)

word_breakdown: Ydyn = yes (they are), maen nhw’n = they are, dda = good (soft mutation of da)
usage_note: Affirmative answer about the quality of something.
pattern_examples: Ydyn, maen nhw’n dda. / Ydyn, maen nhw’n wych.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, they are good / Yes, they are great

welsh: Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda.
image: media/image/Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda..png
audio: media/audio/Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda..m4a
example: Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda.
phonetic: NAHK UD-in, ’din nhw thim un thah
word_breakdown: Nac ydyn = no (they are not), ’dyn nhw ddim = they are not, yn dda = good
usage_note: Negative answer about the quality of something.
pattern_examples: Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda. / Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn wych.
pattern_examples_en: No, they are not good / No, they are not great

english: I want a cup of tea.
word_breakdown: Dw i = I am, eisiau = want, paned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Common way to say you want a cup of tea in Welsh.
pattern_examples: Dw i eisiau paned. / Dw i eisiau coffi.
pattern_examples_en: I want a cup of tea / I want coffee

english: Do you want a cup of tea? (informal)
word_breakdown: Wyt ti = are you, eisiau = want, paned = cup (usually tea)
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone wants a cup of tea.
pattern_examples: Wyt ti eisiau paned? / Wyt ti eisiau coffi?
pattern_examples_en: Do you want a cup of tea? / Do you want coffee?

word_breakdown: Mae = is, Aled = Aled (name), eisiau = wants, coffi = coffee
usage_note: Used to say that Aled wants coffee.
pattern_examples: Mae Aled eisiau coffi. / Mae Aled eisiau te.
pattern_examples_en: Aled wants coffee / Aled wants tea

word_breakdown: Beth = what, wnest ti = did you do, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Informal way to ask what someone did yesterday.
pattern_examples: Beth wnest ti ddoe? / Beth wnaethoch chi ddoe?
pattern_examples_en: What did you do yesterday? / What did you (plural/formal) do yesterday?

word_breakdown: Do = yes (I did), wnes i = I did, siopa = shopping, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Affirmative answer to a past tense question.
pattern_examples: Do, wnes i siopa ddoe. / Do, wnes i siopa’r bore ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, I went shopping yesterday / Yes, I went shopping yesterday morning

welsh: Naddo, wnes i ddim siopa ddoe.
english: No, I did not go shopping yesterday.
image: media/image/Naddo, wnes i ddim siopa ddoe..png
audio: media/audio/Naddo, wnes i ddim siopa ddoe..m4a
example: Naddo, wnes i ddim siopa ddoe.
phonetic: NADH-oh, ness ee thim SHOP-ah THO-ee
word_breakdown: Naddo = no (I did not), wnes i ddim = I did not, siopa = shopping, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Negative answer to a past tense question.
pattern_examples: Naddo, wnes i ddim siopa ddoe. / Naddo, wnes i ddim siopa’r bore ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: No, I did not go shopping yesterday / No, I did not go shopping yesterday morning

word_breakdown: Wnaethoch chi = did you (plural/formal), siopa = shopping, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Formal or plural way to ask if someone went shopping yesterday.
pattern_examples: Wnaethoch chi siopa ddoe? / Wnest ti siopa ddoe?
pattern_examples_en: Did you go shopping yesterday? (plural/formal) / Did you go shopping yesterday? (informal)

word_breakdown: Do = yes (we did), wnaethon ni = we did, siopa = shopping, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Affirmative answer to a past tense question.
pattern_examples: Do, wnaethon ni siopa ddoe. / Do, wnaethon ni siopa’r bore ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, we went shopping yesterday / Yes, we went shopping yesterday morning

welsh: Naddo, wnaethon ni ddim siopa ddoe.
english: No, we did not go shopping yesterday.
image: media/image/Naddo, wnaethon ni ddim siopa ddoe..png
audio: media/audio/Naddo, wnaethon ni ddim siopa ddoe..m4a
example: Naddo, wnaethon ni ddim siopa ddoe.
phonetic: NADH-oh, OO-nay-thon nee thim SHOP-ah THO-ee
word_breakdown: Naddo = no (we did not), wnaethon ni ddim = we did not, siopa = shopping, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Negative answer to a past tense question.
pattern_examples: Naddo, wnaethon ni ddim siopa ddoe. / Naddo, wnaethon ni ddim siopa’r bore ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: No, we did not go shopping yesterday / No, we did not go shopping yesterday morning

word_breakdown: Prynon ni = we bought, fara = bread
usage_note: Used to state what was purchased in the past tense.
pattern_examples: Prynon ni fara. / Prynodd e fara.
pattern_examples_en: We bought bread / He bought bread

word_breakdown: Prynodd e = he bought, fara = bread
usage_note: Used to state what he purchased in the past tense.
pattern_examples: Prynodd e fara. / Prynon ni fara.
pattern_examples_en: He bought bread / We bought bread

word_breakdown: Es i = I went, i’r = to the, dre = town
usage_note: Used to say you went to town.
pattern_examples: Es i i’r dre. / Es i i’r siop.
pattern_examples_en: I went to town / I went to the shop

word_breakdown: Est ti = did you go, i’r = to the, dre = town
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone went to town.
pattern_examples: Est ti i’r dre? / Est ti i’r siop?
pattern_examples_en: Did you go to town? / Did you go to the shop?

english: I did not go to town.
word_breakdown: Es i ddim = I did not go, i’r = to the, dre = town
usage_note: Used to say you didn’t go to town.
pattern_examples: Es i ddim i’r dre. / Es i ddim i’r siop.
pattern_examples_en: I did not go to town / I did not go to the shop

word_breakdown: Ces i = I had, tost = toast, i = for, brecwast = breakfast
usage_note: Used to say what you had for breakfast.
pattern_examples: Ces i tost i frecwast. / Ces i de i frecwast.
pattern_examples_en: I had toast for breakfast / I had tea for breakfast

english: Did you have a cup of tea? (informal)
word_breakdown: Gest ti = did you have, baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone had a cup of tea.
pattern_examples: Gest ti baned? / Gest ti de?
pattern_examples_en: Did you have a cup of tea? / Did you have tea?

english: I did not have a cup of tea.
word_breakdown: Ches i ddim = I did not have, baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Used to say you didn’t have a cup of tea.
pattern_examples: Ches i ddim baned. / Ches i ddim de.
pattern_examples_en: I did not have a cup of tea / I did not have tea

word_breakdown: Sut = how, mae’r = is the, tywydd = weather, heddiw = today
usage_note: Common question to ask about today’s weather.
pattern_examples: Sut mae’r tywydd heddiw? / Sut mae’r tywydd yfory?
pattern_examples_en: How is the weather today? / How is the weather tomorrow?

word_breakdown: Mae hi’n = it is, braf = fine/nice, heddiw = today
usage_note: Used to describe good weather today.
pattern_examples: Mae hi’n braf heddiw. / Mae hi’n heulog heddiw.
pattern_examples_en: It is nice today / It is sunny today

word_breakdown: Oedd hi’n = was it, braf = fine/nice, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Used to ask about weather yesterday.
pattern_examples: Oedd hi’n braf ddoe? / Oedd hi’n heulog ddoe?
pattern_examples_en: Was it nice yesterday? / Was it sunny yesterday?

word_breakdown: Roedd hi’n = it was, braf = fine/nice, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Used to describe good weather yesterday.
pattern_examples: Roedd hi’n braf ddoe. / Roedd hi’n heulog ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: It was nice yesterday / It was sunny yesterday

welsh: Doedd hi ddim yn braf ddoe.
image: media/image/Doedd hi ddim yn braf ddoe..png
audio: media/audio/Doedd hi ddim yn braf ddoe..m4a
example: Doedd hi ddim yn braf ddoe.
phonetic: DOYTH hee thim un BRAV THO-ee
word_breakdown: Doedd hi ddim = it was not, yn = (linking particle), braf = fine/nice, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Used to describe poor weather yesterday.
pattern_examples: Doedd hi ddim yn braf ddoe. / Doedd hi ddim yn heulog ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: It was not nice yesterday / It was not sunny yesterday

word_breakdown: Mae e’n = he is, gallu = able/can, gyrru = to drive
usage_note: Used to say that he can drive.
pattern_examples: Mae e’n gallu gyrru. / Mae e’n gallu darllen.
pattern_examples_en: He can drive / He can read

word_breakdown: Maen nhw’n = they are, gallu = able/can, darllen = to read
usage_note: Used to say that they can read.
pattern_examples: Maen nhw’n gallu darllen. / Maen nhw’n gallu gyrru.
pattern_examples_en: They can read / They can drive

word_breakdown: Siân = Siân (name), yw = is, hi = she
usage_note: Used to introduce or identify a female person.
pattern_examples: Siân yw hi. / Mari yw hi.
pattern_examples_en: She is Siân / She is Mari

word_breakdown: Ydy = is (it/she), hi’n = she/it is, dda = good (soft mutation of da)
usage_note: Used to ask if something or someone is good.
pattern_examples: Ydy hi’n dda? / Ydy hi’n wych?
pattern_examples_en: Is it good? / Is it great?

word_breakdown: Ydy = yes (it/she is), mae hi’n = it/she is, dda = good (soft mutation of da)
usage_note: Affirmative answer to a question about quality.
pattern_examples: Ydy, mae hi’n dda. / Ydy, mae hi’n wych.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, it is good / Yes, it is great

welsh: Nac ydy, dyw hi ddim yn dda.
image: media/image/Nac ydy, dyw hi ddim yn dda..png
audio: media/audio/Nac ydy, dyw hi ddim yn dda..m4a
example: Nac ydy, dyw hi ddim yn dda.
phonetic: NAHK ud-ee, DYOO hee thim un thah
word_breakdown: Nac ydy = no (it is not), dyw hi ddim = it is not, yn dda = good
usage_note: Negative answer about quality.
pattern_examples: Nac ydy, dyw hi ddim yn dda. / Nac ydy, dyw hi ddim yn wych.
pattern_examples_en: No, it is not good / No, it is not great

word_breakdown: Ydyn nhw’n = are they, dda = good (soft mutation of da)
usage_note: Used to ask if a group is good.
pattern_examples: Ydyn nhw’n dda? / Ydyn nhw’n wych?
pattern_examples_en: Are they good? / Are they great?

word_breakdown: Ydyn = yes (they are), maen nhw’n = they are, dda = good
usage_note: Affirmative answer about a group’s quality.
pattern_examples: Ydyn, maen nhw’n dda. / Ydyn, maen nhw’n wych.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, they are good / Yes, they are great

welsh: Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda.
image: media/image/Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda..png
audio: media/audio/Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda..m4a
example: Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda.
phonetic: NAHK UD-in, ’din nhw thim un thah
word_breakdown: Nac ydyn = no (they are not), ’dyn nhw ddim = they are not, yn dda = good
usage_note: Negative answer about a group’s quality.
pattern_examples: Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn dda. / Nac ydyn, ’dyn nhw ddim yn wych.
pattern_examples_en: No, they are not good / No, they are not great

english: May I have a cup of tea?
word_breakdown: Gaf i = may I have, baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Polite request for a cup of tea.
pattern_examples: Gaf i baned? / Gaf i de?
pattern_examples_en: May I have a cup of tea? / May I have tea?

english: You may have a cup of tea. (informal)
word_breakdown: Cei = you may (informal), baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Informal way to give permission.
pattern_examples: Cei baned. / Cei de.
pattern_examples_en: You may have a cup of tea / You may have tea

english: You may not have a cup of tea. (informal)
word_breakdown: Na chei = you may not (informal), baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Informal way to refuse permission.
pattern_examples: Na chei baned. / Na chei de.
pattern_examples_en: You may not have a cup of tea / You may not have tea

english: You may have a cup of tea. (formal/plural)
word_breakdown: Cewch = you may (formal/plural), baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Formal or polite way to give permission.
pattern_examples: Cewch baned. / Cewch de.
pattern_examples_en: You may have a cup of tea / You may have tea

english: You may not have a cup of tea. (formal/plural)
word_breakdown: Na chewch = you may not (formal/plural), baned = a cup (usually of tea)
usage_note: Formal or polite way to refuse permission.
pattern_examples: Na chewch baned. / Na chewch de.
pattern_examples_en: You may not have a cup of tea / You may not have tea

welsh: Dw i’n gweithio yn y coleg.
image: media/image/Dw i’n gweithio yn y coleg..png
audio: media/audio/Dw i’n gweithio yn y coleg..m4a
example: Dw i’n gweithio yn y coleg.
phonetic: DOO een GWUR-thyo un uh KOLL-eg
word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, gweithio = working, yn y = in the, coleg = college
usage_note: Used to state where you work.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n gweithio yn y coleg. / Dw i’n gweithio mewn coleg.
pattern_examples_en: I work in the college / I work in a college

word_breakdown: Dw i’n = I am, gweithio = working, mewn = in a, coleg = college
usage_note: Used to state that you work in a college without specifying which.
pattern_examples: Dw i’n gweithio mewn coleg. / Dw i’n gweithio yn y coleg.
pattern_examples_en: I work in a college / I work in the college

word_breakdown: Mae = there is, car = car, gyda fi = with me (I have)
usage_note: Used to say you own or have a car.
pattern_examples: Mae car gyda fi. / Mae tŷ gyda fi.
pattern_examples_en: I have a car / I have a house

word_breakdown: Oes = is there/do you have, car = car, gyda ti = with you (informal)
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone has a car.
pattern_examples: Oes car gyda ti? / Oes tŷ gyda ti?
pattern_examples_en: Do you have a car? / Do you have a house?

english: I do not have a car.
word_breakdown: Does dim = there is not, car = car, gyda fi = with me
usage_note: Used to say you do not have a car.
pattern_examples: Does dim car gyda fi. / Does dim tŷ gyda fi.
pattern_examples_en: I do not have a car / I do not have a house

word_breakdown: Roedd = there was/I had, pen = head, tost = sore, gyda fi = with me
usage_note: Used to say you had a headache.
pattern_examples: Roedd pen tost gyda fi. / Roedd stumog tost gyda fi.
pattern_examples_en: I had a headache / I had a stomach ache

word_breakdown: Roedd = there was/I had, annwyd = cold (illness), arna i = on me
usage_note: Used to say you had a cold.
pattern_examples: Roedd annwyd arna i. / Roedd peswch arna i.
pattern_examples_en: I had a cold / I had a cough

english: I used to live in Swansea.
word_breakdown: Ro’n i’n = I was/I used to be, byw = live, yn = in, Abertawe = Swansea
usage_note: Used to talk about where you lived in the past.
pattern_examples: Ro’n i’n byw yn Abertawe. / Ro’n i’n byw yn Llanelli.
pattern_examples_en: I used to live in Swansea / I used to live in Llanelli

welsh: Ro’t ti’n gweithio yn y coleg.
english: You used to work in the college. (informal)
image: media/image/Ro’t ti’n gweithio yn y coleg..png
audio: media/audio/Ro’t ti’n gweithio yn y coleg..m4a
example: Ro’t ti’n gweithio yn y coleg.
phonetic: ROHT tee’n GWUR-thyo un uh KOLL-eg
word_breakdown: Ro’t ti’n = you were/you used to, gweithio = work, yn y = in the, coleg = college
usage_note: Informal way to say someone used to work in the college.
pattern_examples: Ro’t ti’n gweithio yn y coleg. / Ro’t ti’n gweithio mewn coleg.
pattern_examples_en: You used to work in the college / You used to work in a college

word_breakdown: Dw i wedi = I have, blino = tired
usage_note: Used to say you are tired.
pattern_examples: Dw i wedi blino. / Dw i wedi blino’n lân.
pattern_examples_en: I am tired / I am completely tired

word_breakdown: Faint o’r gloch = what time (of the clock), yw hi = is it
usage_note: Used to ask for the time.
pattern_examples: Faint o’r gloch yw hi? / Faint o’r gloch yw e?
pattern_examples_en: What time is it? / What time is it? (masc.)

english: What is the price of petrol?
word_breakdown: Faint = how much/what, yw = is, pris = price, y petrol = the petrol
usage_note: Used to ask how much petrol costs.
pattern_examples: Faint yw pris y petrol? / Faint yw pris y bara?
pattern_examples_en: What is the price of petrol? / What is the price of bread?

word_breakdown: Bydd hi’n = it will be, braf = fine/nice, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to describe good weather tomorrow.
pattern_examples: Bydd hi’n braf yfory. / Bydd hi’n heulog yfory.
pattern_examples_en: It will be nice tomorrow / It will be sunny tomorrow

word_breakdown: Fydd hi’n = will it be, braf = fine/nice, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to ask about the weather tomorrow.
pattern_examples: Fydd hi’n braf yfory? / Fydd hi’n heulog yfory?
pattern_examples_en: Will it be nice tomorrow? / Will it be sunny tomorrow?

welsh: Fydd hi ddim yn braf yfory.
english: It will not be nice tomorrow.
image: media/image/Fydd hi ddim yn braf yfory..png
audio: media/audio/Fydd hi ddim yn braf yfory..m4a
example: Fydd hi ddim yn braf yfory.
phonetic: VITH hee thim un BRAV uh-VO-ree
word_breakdown: Fydd hi ddim = it will not, yn braf = nice, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to describe poor weather tomorrow.
pattern_examples: Fydd hi ddim yn braf yfory. / Fydd hi ddim yn heulog yfory.
pattern_examples_en: It will not be nice tomorrow / It will not be sunny tomorrow

word_breakdown: Bydda i’n = I will be, gweithio = working, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to say you will be working the next day.
pattern_examples: Bydda i’n gweithio yfory. / Bydda i’n mynd yfory.
pattern_examples_en: I will be working tomorrow / I will be going tomorrow

word_breakdown: Byddwn ni’n = we will be, mynd = going, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to say your group will be going somewhere the next day.
pattern_examples: Byddwn ni’n mynd yfory. / Byddwn ni’n gweithio yfory.
pattern_examples_en: We will be going tomorrow / We will be working tomorrow

word_breakdown: Byddan nhw’n = they will be, dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to say that others will be coming the next day.
pattern_examples: Byddan nhw’n dod yfory. / Byddan nhw’n mynd yfory.
pattern_examples_en: They will be coming tomorrow / They will be going tomorrow

word_breakdown: Fyddi di’n = will you be, dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Informal way to ask if someone will be coming the next day.
pattern_examples: Fyddi di’n dod yfory? / Fyddi di’n mynd yfory?
pattern_examples_en: Will you be coming tomorrow? / Will you be going tomorrow?

english: Yes, I will be coming tomorrow.
word_breakdown: Bydda = yes (I will), dw i’n = I am, dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Affirmative answer to a future tense question.
pattern_examples: Bydda, dw i’n dod yfory. / Bydda, dw i’n mynd yfory.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, I will be coming tomorrow / Yes, I will be going tomorrow

welsh: Na fydda, dw i ddim yn dod yfory.
english: No, I will not be coming tomorrow.
image: media/image/Na fydda, dw i ddim yn dod yfory..png
audio: media/audio/Na fydda, dw i ddim yn dod yfory..m4a
example: Na fydda, dw i ddim yn dod yfory.
phonetic: NA VUTH-ah, DOO ee thim un DOD uh-VO-ree
word_breakdown: Na fydda = no (I will not), dw i ddim = I am not, yn dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Negative answer to a future tense question.
pattern_examples: Na fydda, dw i ddim yn dod yfory. / Na fydda, dw i ddim yn mynd yfory.
pattern_examples_en: No, I will not be coming tomorrow / No, I will not be going tomorrow

word_breakdown: Fyddwch chi’n = will you be (formal/plural), dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Formal or plural way to ask if someone will be coming the next day.
pattern_examples: Fyddwch chi’n dod yfory? / Fyddwch chi’n mynd yfory?
pattern_examples_en: Will you be coming tomorrow? / Will you be going tomorrow?

english: Yes, we will be coming tomorrow.
word_breakdown: Byddwn = yes (we will), ’dyn ni’n = we are, dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Affirmative answer to a future tense question.
pattern_examples: Byddwn, ’dyn ni’n dod yfory. / Byddwn, ’dyn ni’n mynd yfory.
pattern_examples_en: Yes, we will be coming tomorrow / Yes, we will be going tomorrow

welsh: Na fyddwn, ’dyn ni ddim yn dod yfory.
english: No, we will not be coming tomorrow.
image: media/image/Na fyddwn, ’dyn ni ddim yn dod yfory..png
audio: media/audio/Na fyddwn, ’dyn ni ddim yn dod yfory..m4a
example: Na fyddwn, ’dyn ni ddim yn dod yfory.
phonetic: NA BUTH-oon, ’din nee thim un DOD uh-VO-ree
word_breakdown: Na fyddwn = no (we will not), ’dyn ni ddim = we are not, yn dod = coming, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Negative answer to a future tense question.
pattern_examples: Na fyddwn, ’dyn ni ddim yn dod yfory. / Na fyddwn, ’dyn ni ddim yn mynd yfory.
pattern_examples_en: No, we will not be coming tomorrow / No, we will not be going tomorrow

word_breakdown: Dewch = come (formal/plural), yma = here
usage_note: Formal or plural way to tell people to come here.
pattern_examples: Dewch yma! / Dewch i mewn!
pattern_examples_en: Come here! / Come in!

word_breakdown: Codwch = get up (formal/plural), nawr = now
usage_note: Formal or plural command to stand or get up.
pattern_examples: Codwch nawr! / Codwch yn araf.
pattern_examples_en: Get up now! / Get up slowly.

word_breakdown: Gwnewch = do (formal/plural), ymarfer = exercise
usage_note: Formal or plural command to complete an exercise.
pattern_examples: Gwnewch ymarfer! / Gwnewch waith cartref.
pattern_examples_en: Do the exercise! / Do homework.

word_breakdown: Coda = get up (informal), nawr = now
usage_note: Informal command to stand or get up.
pattern_examples: Coda nawr! / Coda’n araf.
pattern_examples_en: Get up now! / Get up slowly.

word_breakdown: Dere = come (informal), yma = here
usage_note: Informal way to tell someone to come here.
pattern_examples: Dere yma! / Dere i mewn!
pattern_examples_en: Come here! / Come in!

word_breakdown: Gwna = do (informal), gwaith = work
usage_note: Informal command to do work.
pattern_examples: Gwna gwaith! / Gwna waith cartref.
pattern_examples_en: Do work! / Do homework.

word_breakdown: Rhaid i fi = I must, gyrru = drive, nawr = now
usage_note: Used to say you must drive immediately.
pattern_examples: Rhaid i fi gyrru nawr. / Rhaid i fi weithio nawr.
pattern_examples_en: I must drive now / I must work now

welsh: Oes rhaid i ti ddysgu heddiw?
english: Do you have to study today?
image: media/image/Oes rhaid i ti ddysgu heddiw.png
audio: media/audio/Oes rhaid i ti ddysgu heddiw.m4a
example: Oes rhaid i ti ddysgu heddiw?
phonetic: OYS RHIDE ee tee THUHS-gee HETH-dee-oo
word_breakdown: Oes rhaid i ti = must you / do you have to, ddysgu = study, heddiw = today
usage_note: Used to ask if someone is obliged to study today.
pattern_examples: Oes rhaid i ti ddysgu heddiw? / Oes rhaid i ti weithio heddiw?
pattern_examples_en: Do you have to study today? / Do you have to work today?

welsh: Does dim rhaid i fi stopio.
image: media/image/Does dim rhaid i fi stopio.png
audio: media/audio/Does dim rhaid i fi stopio.m4a
example: Does dim rhaid i fi stopio.
phonetic: DOYSS dim RHIDE ee vee STOP-yoh
word_breakdown: Does dim rhaid i fi = I do not have to, stopio = stop
usage_note: Used to say there is no need to stop.
pattern_examples: Does dim rhaid i fi stopio / Does dim rhaid i fi fynd.
pattern_examples_en: I don’t have to stop / I don’t have to go.

word_breakdown: Rhaid i fi = I must, beidio = not, gyrru = drive
usage_note: Used to say you must refrain from driving.
pattern_examples: Rhaid i fi beidio gyrru / Rhaid i fi beidio siarad.
pattern_examples_en: I must not drive / I must not speak.

welsh: Ar ôl i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n darllen.
english: After I go to the class, I read.
image: media/image/Ar ôl i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n darllen.png
audio: media/audio/Ar ôl i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n darllen.m4a
example: Ar ôl i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n darllen.
phonetic: Ar OHL ee vee VIND eer DOSS-barth, doo een DAR-hlen
word_breakdown: Ar ôl = after, i fi = I, fynd = go, i’r dosbarth = to the class, dw i’n darllen = I read
usage_note: Used to describe what you do after going to class.
pattern_examples: Ar ôl i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n darllen / Ar ôl i fi fynd i’r siop, dw i’n prynu coffi.
pattern_examples_en: After I go to the class, I read / After I go to the shop, I buy coffee.

welsh: Cyn i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n gyrru i’r coleg.
english: Before I go to the class, I drive to the college.
image: media/image/Cyn i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n gyrru i’r coleg.png
audio: media/audio/Cyn i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n gyrru i’r coleg.m4a
example: Cyn i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n gyrru i’r coleg.
phonetic: KIN ee vee VIND eer DOSS-barth, doo een GUR-ee eer KOL-eg
word_breakdown: Cyn = before, i fi = I, fynd = go, i’r dosbarth = to the class, dw i’n gyrru = I drive, i’r coleg = to the college
usage_note: Used to describe what you do before going to class.
pattern_examples: Cyn i fi fynd i’r dosbarth, dw i’n gyrru i’r coleg / Cyn i fi fynd i’r siop, dw i’n cael brecwast.
pattern_examples_en: Before I go to the class, I drive to the college / Before I go to the shop, I have breakfast.

english: There is coffee in the café.
word_breakdown: Mae = there is, coffi = coffee, yn y = in the, caffi = café
usage_note: Used to state that coffee is available in the café.
pattern_examples: Mae coffi yn y caffi / Mae bara yn y siop.
pattern_examples_en: There is coffee in the café / There is bread in the shop.

english: Is there tea in the café?
word_breakdown: Oes = is there, te = tea, yn y = in the, caffi = café
usage_note: Used to ask if tea is available in the café.
pattern_examples: Oes te yn y caffi? / Oes siwgr yn y caffi?
pattern_examples_en: Is there tea in the café? / Is there sugar in the café?

welsh: Does dim te yn y caffi.
english: There is no tea in the café.
image: media/image/Does dim te yn y caffi.png
audio: media/audio/Does dim te yn y caffi.m4a
example: Does dim te yn y caffi.
phonetic: DOYSS dim TEH un uh KAFF-ee
word_breakdown: Does dim = there is no, te = tea, yn y = in the, caffi = café
usage_note: Used to state that tea is not available in the café.
pattern_examples: Does dim te yn y caffi / Does dim coffi yn y caffi.
pattern_examples_en: There is no tea in the café / There is no coffee in the café.

word_breakdown: Mae’r = the (is), te’n = tea is, oer = cold
usage_note: Used to say the tea is cold.
pattern_examples: Mae’r te’n oer / Mae’r coffi’n oer.
pattern_examples_en: The tea is cold / The coffee is cold.

word_breakdown: Ydy’r = is the, te’n = tea is, oer = cold
usage_note: Used to ask if the tea is cold.
pattern_examples: Ydy’r te’n oer? / Ydy’r coffi’n oer?
pattern_examples_en: Is the tea cold? / Is the coffee cold?

word_breakdown: Dyw’r = is not (the), te = tea, ddim = not, yn oer = cold
usage_note: Used to state that the tea is not cold.
pattern_examples: Dyw’r te ddim yn oer / Dyw’r coffi ddim yn boeth.
pattern_examples_en: The tea is not cold / The coffee is not hot.

welsh: Ei gar e yw car gwyrdd.
english: His car is a green car.
image: media/image/Ei gar e yw car gwyrdd.png
audio: media/audio/Ei gar e yw car gwyrdd.m4a
example: Ei gar e yw car gwyrdd.
phonetic: Ay GAR eh yoo kar GWEERDH
word_breakdown: Ei = his, gar = car, e = he, yw = is, car gwyrdd = green car
usage_note: Used to describe a male’s car colour.
pattern_examples: Ei gar e yw car gwyrdd / Ei dŷ e yw tŷ mawr.
pattern_examples_en: His car is a green car / His house is a big house.

welsh: Ei char hi yw car coch.
english: Her car is a red car.
image: media/image/Ei char hi yw car coch.png
audio: media/audio/Ei char hi yw car coch.m4a
example: Ei char hi yw car coch.
phonetic: Ay KHAR hee yoo kar KOHKH
word_breakdown: Ei = her, char = car (mutated), hi = she, yw = is, car coch = red car
usage_note: Used to describe a female’s car colour.
pattern_examples: Ei char hi yw car coch / Ei thŷ hi yw tŷ bach.
pattern_examples_en: Her car is a red car / Her house is a small house.

welsh: Ein car ni yw car du.
english: Our car is a black car.
image: media/image/Ein car ni yw car du.png
audio: media/audio/Ein car ni yw car du.m4a
example: Ein car ni yw car du.
phonetic: EIN kar nee yoo kar dee
word_breakdown: Ein = our, car = car, ni = we, yw = is, car du = black car
usage_note: Used to describe our car colour.
pattern_examples: Ein car ni yw car du / Ein tŷ ni yw dŷ mawr.
pattern_examples_en: Our car is a black car / Our house is a big house.

welsh: Eu car nhw yw car glas.
english: Their car is a blue car.
image: media/image/Eu car nhw yw car glas.png
audio: media/audio/Eu car nhw yw car glas.m4a
example: Eu car nhw yw car glas.
phonetic: Ay kar noo yoo kar glass
word_breakdown: Eu = their, car = car, nhw = they, yw = is, car glas = blue car
usage_note: Used to describe someone else’s car colour.
pattern_examples: Eu car nhw yw car glas / Eu tŷ nhw yw tŷ bach.
pattern_examples_en: Their car is a blue car / Their house is a small house.

welsh: Roedd rhaid i fi weithio ddoe.
image: media/image/Roedd rhaid i fi weithio ddoe.png
audio: media/audio/Roedd rhaid i fi weithio ddoe.m4a
example: Roedd rhaid i fi weithio ddoe.
phonetic: ROITH RHIDE ee vee GWAY-thyo THOEY
word_breakdown: Roedd rhaid i fi = I had to, weithio = work, ddoe = yesterday
usage_note: Used to state an obligation you had in the past.
pattern_examples: Roedd rhaid i fi weithio ddoe / Roedd rhaid i fi aros gartref ddoe.
pattern_examples_en: I had to work yesterday / I had to stay home yesterday.

welsh: Bydd rhaid i fi weithio yfory.
english: I will have to work tomorrow.
image: media/image/Bydd rhaid i fi weithio yfory.png
audio: media/audio/Bydd rhaid i fi weithio yfory.m4a
example: Bydd rhaid i fi weithio yfory.
phonetic: BITH RHIDE ee vee GWAY-thyo uh-VOR-ee
word_breakdown: Bydd rhaid i fi = I will have to, weithio = work, yfory = tomorrow
usage_note: Used to state an obligation you will have in the future.
pattern_examples: Bydd rhaid i fi weithio yfory / Bydd rhaid i fi fynd i’r dref yfory.
pattern_examples_en: I will have to work tomorrow / I will have to go to town tomorrow.
